title: Question 15
prompt: The father wants to modify the seesaw so that the weight of his son pushes down with enough force to lift him up. In order to do this, he could
description:
Click the one best answer to each question.

A simple lever can be constructed by laying a bar over a fulcrum, or pivot point. The longer the distance between the fulcrum and the force end of the bar, the less force is needed to lift the weight on the other end. A boy wants to play on a seesaw with his father, but the boy is not heavy enough to lift his father off the ground by sitting at one end. The father realizes that the seesaw is a lever. With the father sitting at one end, the center of the seesaw sits on a fulcrum.
feedback: A seesaw-type lever has a fulcrum and a load on one side of the bar that needs to be lifted, in this case, the father. Downward force on the other side of the bar—in this case, the son’s weight—lifts the load that is on the other end. To lift the same load with less force, the fulcrum needs to be closer to the load. The closer to the load that the fulcrum is, the less force is needed to lift the weight.
